Subjective: Back pain, right leg radiation to foot x 1.5 weeks, worsening. Pain in posterior thigh, lateral lower leg. Discomfort all day, no specific triggers. Unable to sleep due to pain. Pain stops movement, but strength intact. Dull sensation on lateral right lower leg. Tingling in same area as pain. Stopped working at supermarket due to lifting. Tried max doses paracetamol/ibuprofen, no relief. No bowel/bladder incontinence. No saddle anesthesia. Request: Wants pain relief, get rid of pain.
Objective: Appears in pain on ambulation to couch. No visible abnormalities of legs or back on inspection. Palpation of back: no vertebral tenderness. Straight leg raise, right: positive for pain. Straight leg raise, left: negative. Sensation: duller on lateral right lower leg compared to left. Strength: 5/5 bilateral lower extremities, though pain limits movement. Reflexes: normal bilateral ankle jerks. Plantar response: downgoing bilateral. Sensation to light touch: difference noted between left and right lower leg/foot, right duller.
Assessment: Lumbar disc herniation, right-sided sciatica. Nerve root compression suspected. Pain is neuropathic in nature. No red flags for cauda equina syndrome (no saddle anesthesia, no bowel/bladder dysfunction, strength intact).
Plan:
- Prescribe Pregabalin for neuropathic pain. Start low dose, titrate slowly. Counsel on side effects, including driving restrictions (no driving while starting/titrating dose or if side effects occur, at least 1 week post-dose change). Goal: improve sleep and pain.
- Recommend physiotherapy for exercises to improve flexibility and potentially reduce disc compression.
- Advise on conservative management, surgery not indicated currently.
- Safety netting: Contact immediately or go to ED if worsening symptoms, specifically loss of sensation/numbness in 'riding breeches' area, new bowel/bladder incontinence, or significant leg weakness.
- Follow-up: Telephone appointment in 1 week to assess pain relief and medication tolerance.
- Patient to obtain Pregabalin from pharmacy.
